title: 111_hr2490
content: The Act titled "Generating Reinvestment Opportunities With America's Small Businesses Act of 2009" or the "GROW America's Small Businesses Act of 2009" allows for deferred payment of tax by certain small businesses under a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code. An eligible small business can choose to pay the tax in 4 equal installments, with a maximum limit based on the tax amount for the year, contributions to a GROW Account, or $275,000 minus prior tax elections. Eligible small businesses are defined as those actively engaged in business activities. The tax payment for eligible small businesses can be made in 4 equal installments if certain conditions are met, including having gross receipts of $12,000,000 or less, meeting active business requirements, and using an accrual method of accounting. Rules similar to section 448(c) apply, and interest is applicable on installment payments. The installment payment schedule for eligible small businesses allows for payments to be made in 4 equal installments. The first installment must be paid by the due date, with subsequent installments due 1 year after the previous one. The due date for the first installment can be chosen by the taxpayer or set to 2 years after the tax payment deadline. The installment payment schedule for eligible small businesses allows for payments to be made in 4 equal installments. An additional deferral of tax can be granted if an eligible small business meets the employment increase requirement for the second taxable year following the election. The employment increase requirement for eligible small businesses involves having a greater average number of employees in the last calendar quarter compared to before the establishment of the GROW Account. Full-time employees are those working at least 35 hours per week. Additionally, called-up reservists' salary maintenance is considered an employment increase. The text discusses compensation for Ready Reserve/National Guard employees on active duty, ensuring it meets the active duty wage differential. Special rules apply for interest calculation on tax payments. Special rules apply for partners and S corporation shareholders in eligible small businesses when making tax elections and calculating tax payments. Special rules apply for partners and S corporation shareholders in eligible small businesses when making tax elections and calculating tax payments. The limitation under subsection (b)(3) is applied at both the partnership and partner levels for partners in a partnership. Similar rules apply to shareholders in an S corporation. If the taxpayer no longer meets the requirements of subsection (c)(1)(A) or there is an ownership change, the extension of time for tax payment may be accelerated. The extension of time for tax payment may cease if there is an ownership change, and the unpaid tax must be paid by the due date for filing the return of tax for the first taxable year following the change. Rules similar to section 382 apply to corporations, and rules similar to section 6166(e) apply for proration of deficiency to installments. A GROW Account is defined for this section. "A GROW Account is a trust created for the exclusive benefit of an eligible small business, with specific requirements for contributions, trustee qualifications, and asset composition." "A GROW Account trust must consist of cash or interest-bearing obligations, not commingled with other assets. Funds can only be used as security for a loan to the business or for repayment, and the grantor is taxed as the owner." The GROW Account owner is subject to tax according to specific regulations. Payments to the account are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year if made within 3 1/2 months after the year ends. Definitions related to salary maintenance of called-up reservists are also provided. The text chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for employees who are members of the Ready Reserve or National Guard and are called up for qualified active duty. The terms National Guard, Ready Reserve, and qualified active duty are defined in accordance with specific sections of the United States Code. Employees who are members of the Ready Reserve or National Guard called up for qualified active duty are entitled to reemployment rights, benefits, and a leave of absence under specific sections of the United States Code. This includes hospitalization incident to such active duty. The active duty wage differential for Ready Reserve/National Guard employees on qualified active duty is calculated based on their daily wage differential multiplied by the number of days on active duty. The daily wage differential is the excess of the employee's average daily compensation over the period. The average daily employer-provided compensation for an employee on qualified active duty is calculated based on the average daily compensation paid by the employer for the 1-year period before the start of active duty, adjusted for cost-of-living and other increases. The term 'compensation' refers to remuneration for employment deductible under section 162(a)(1). Average daily military pay for Ready Reserve/National Guard employees is based on their military pay and allowances during qualified active duty. The term 'military pay' refers to pay defined in section 101(21) of title 37, United States Code, and 'allowances' refer to allowances payable to members of the Armed Forces under chapter 7 of the same title. The Secretary may require reporting as deemed necessary, and this section applies to taxes for taxable years after enactment and before January 1, 2011. The section amends the priority of lenders regarding loans secured by GROW accounts with banks, providing protection for loans made without knowledge of existing liens. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 62 of the Code. The amendments made by this section extend the time for tax payment for certain small businesses. A study will be conducted by the Comptroller General to evaluate the impact of the GROW America's Small Businesses Act of 2009 on businesses' capital funding needs. The report is due by March 31, 2011. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the House of Representatives and the Senate Committee on Finance with recommendations for legislative or administrative changes based on a study evaluating the impact of the GROW America's Small Businesses Act of 2009 on businesses' capital funding needs.
